qas.question: Who believe they are the one and only chosen few?

plausible_answers.text: have exclusive access to absolute truth, generally through revelation or encounter with the Divine

plausible_answers.text: through revelation or encounter with the Divine

qas.question: How does the New Age movement believe it has access to absolute truth??

context: Adherents of different religions generally disagree as to how to best worship God and what is God's plan for mankind, if there is one. There are different approaches to reconciling the contradictory claims of monotheistic religions. One view is taken by <a0_0><a1_0>exclusivists<a1_0/><a0_0/>, who believe they are the chosen people or <b5_0>have exclusive access to <b8_0>absolute truth<b8_0/>, generally <b9_0>through revelation or encounter with the Divine<b9_0/><b5_0/>, which adherents of other religions do not. Another view is religious <a2_0>pluralism<a2_0/>. A pluralist typically believes that his religion is the right one, but does not deny the partial truth of other religions. An example of a pluralist view in Christianity is <a3_0><b6_0>supersessionism<b6_0/><a3_0/>, i.e., the belief that one's religion is the fulfillment of previous religions. A third approach is relativistic inclusivism, where everybody is seen as equally right; an example being <a4_0>universalism<a4_0/>: the doctrine that <b7_0>salvation<b7_0/> is eventually available for everyone. A fourth approach is syncretism, mixing different elements from different religions. An example of syncretism is the New Age movement.
